info.title: Plixus Core API 1.0
info.description:
# Introduction
This introduction describes the basics of the REST API for Plixus Core on the Central Unit (CU).
## Before you start
Televic Conference's Plixus Core API (for the central unit) was created to create custom solutions and integrate with your own API.  With the Plixus API you can perform two types of functions:
* **Publication** of events occuring in the meeting room   
* **External control** of the meeting room

## Event notifications
The Plixus Core API uses a **Publish/Subscribe** mechanism, this means that external clients that connect to the API can choose to which events they subscribe and get information from. The API contains commands to subscribe or unsubscribe from each of the modules. Each module contains specific functionality to manage and configure meetings. The following modules are available:

* **Audio**: module to configure general, system wide audio settings
* **AudioDynamicsProcessor**: module for all runtime modifications of your active audio dynamics processor configuration
* **AudioDynamicsProcessorConfigurations**: module to create, edit audio dynamics processor configurations
* **AudioRouting**: module for all runtime modifications of your active audio routing configuration
* **AudioRoutingConfigurations**: module to create, edit and delete audio routing configurations
* **Buttons**: module to manage all buttons events in your meeting room
> Button events may not always take place, because certain operations in CoCon such as voting sessions, use specific buttons. Only when the session is ended the buttons become available again.
* **Discussion**: module with operator functionality. Change and retrieve microphone states or change conference settings
* **Intercom**: module to set up calls between microphone units
* **Interpretation**: module for runtime modifications and information of the active interpretation configuration
* **InterpretationConfigurations**: module to create, edit and delete interpretation configurations
* **InterpretationExternal**: module for runtime modifications and information of the active external interpretation configuration
* **Leds**: module to manage all LED events in your meeting room
> LED events may not always take place, because certain operations in CoCon such as voting sessions use certain LEDs. Only when the voting session is ended, LED events become available.
* **Meeting**: module to manage general meeting functions such as meeting state
* **Messaging**: module to send messages to seats and booths
* **Recording**: module to manage recording on the Central Unit
* **Resources**: module to manage all resources present in your setup
* **Room**: module to manage the meeting room, initialize units, create booths and manage the room layout
* **System**: module for general system wide settings such as licensing and date and time format
* **Users**: module for user management with authentication, user roles and permissions
* **Video**: module for runtime modifications of video configuration to route the video inputs and outputs to one of the 6 available video streams
* **VideoConfigurations**: module to create, edit and delete video configurations
* **Voting**: module for basic management of voting sessions
* **WirelessAccessPoints**: module to manage the wireless access points that are connected to the system
* **WirelessAuthentication**: module to manage the wireless authentication method used by the wireless access point
* **WirelessChannels**: module to manage the wireless channels used by the wireless access point

# Set up and use the Plixus Core API
## General
The Plixus Core API consists of a number of URI's (*Uniform Resource Indentifier*) which are exchanged between the API client and the Plixus engine over a TCP/IP-connection. The Plixus Central Unit hosts the API and is available on the IP address of the Central Unit.
The API uses two (or more) parallel HTTP-connections:
* A **Notification** connection that the client and the CU keep open in case any information needs to be transferred from the CU to the client.


* Any other connection that is used to transfer **information from the client to the CU**.

The client needs to initialize the notification connection and it is kept open by both sides. Two scenarios can occur:
* The CU has information to send to the client and therefore uses the notification connection. When the information is transferred, the connection is closed (as per the HTTP standard). Therefore, the client needs to create a new notification connection. The CU guarantees that no information is lost during this time period where the client is not connected to the CU. 
> Note that you need to create a new notification connection within 60 seconds. If not, the CU discards the client data.
* The HTTP-connection times out before the CU has any information to send to the client. At this point, the client needs to create a new notification connection. Also in this scenario, the CU guarantees that no information is lost.
## REST/JSON example
Below you can find a short description and example how to create and use the API connection with the CU using the **REST/JSON format**. 
The first URI you need to send to the Plixus API is the **connect URI**, which you can find in the Notification module (/api/notification/connect). This returns a JSON string as reply, which looks like the following example:

``` *{"connectionId":"3f5b8afe-6efb-4428-8762-e39d42a0762d"}*  ```
    
This returns the **Id** of the connection that you need to use to open the notification connection and make a new polling request. When the connection is established, the CU can send updates to the client. After the client receives information from the CU, it must re-establish the connection with the CU.

## Server return values
For feedback of the API communication between the client and the CU, the API uses **HTTP response codes**.

If unchecked, the voting results are shown during a vote (by means of a bar chart) > current functionality).

tags.name: Notification
tags.description:
With the Notification module you can subscribe to or unscribe from one or more events. By default you are *subscribed to all events*. If some event information is not relevant for your system, you can unsubscribe from these modules using the unsubscribe command.

The REST API does not allow to send messages from the server-side to the client-side by default. Therefore the Plixus ERS API uses **long polling** to send messages. This creates a connection between client and server that is kept open for a longer period of time. Over this connection, the server can then send information when and if it is available. When an event occurs this results in a **HTTP 200 OK**, when there is no event this results in a **HTTP 408 Request-Timeout**.

tags.name: Events
tags.description:
This is an exhaustive list of all events that can occur across all modules. All these events
generate metadata. With the Notification module you can subscribe to these events.

tags.name: Resources
tags.description:
With the resources module you can manage all your resources, you can get an overview of all
resources or upload and remove resources. A typical example of a resource is the background image
you use for the room layout.

tags.name: Users
tags.description:
The User module contains basic user management features. The user model consists of three different **user roles**:
* Technician
* Operator
* Chairman

Each role has specific **permissions** that determine what the user can do in the conference system. Each user can have one or more user roles. For example a technician has to permission to create and edit room layouts, while an operator or chairman only has the permission to view the room layout.

Besides the user roles and permissions, you can use this module to **authenticate** users by assigning a password to this user.

tags.name: System
tags.description:
Use the System module to configure system wide settings such as:
* IP settigns
* Date and time format
* Loglevel

In the System module you can also find the calls to manage your software licenses to activate one or more features.

tags.name: Room
tags.description:
With the room module you can manage your meeting room. This module contains calls to initialize the units, create and remove desks in booths. 

You can also set the **capabilities** of a seat. A capability is a functionality that is possible and active on that seat. The capability is defined by the type of unit. A couple of examples of capabilities are *voting, discussion, interpretation and video*. Besides the capabilities, you can also set the **role** of the seat. A seat can have a:
* Delegate
* Chairman
* VIP role. 

The chairman and VIP role have additional functionalities:
* Chairman: can always activate its microphone and has prior/next and start/stop vote function
* VIP: has the same speech priority as a chairman but without the prior/next and start/stop vote function


![alt text](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/televic-conference/plixus-api-docs/master/img/RoomModule.jpg "Room elements")

tags.name: Audio
tags.description:
With the Audio module you can **set**, **edit** and **retrieve** all **general (sytem wide) audio settings**. In the Audio module you can for example find a call to change the default volume of all channel selectors, present in the room. 
Use the Audio module to retrieve the details of the active DSP configuration and use the *Change the active dsp configuration for the room* call to change these DSP settings.

tags.name: AudioDynamicsProcessor
tags.description: Use the AudioDynamicsProcessor module for all runtime modifications of your active audio dynamics processor configuration.

tags.name: AudioDynamicsProcessorConfigurations
tags.description: The AudioDynamicsProcessorConfigurations module is responsible for creating, editing and storing audio dynamics processor configurations.

tags.name: AudioRouting
tags.description:
Use the Audiorouting module for all runtime modifications of your active audio routing configuration. With the calls in this module you can modify the settings of the active configuration, change the state of a node in the routing matrix or change the maximum number of language channels.

> Note that changes made to the configuration are not saved by default, you need to invoke the save call for this.
The AudioRouting module is indepent of the storage of the routing configurations, for managing configurations you can use the AudioRoutingConfigurations module or your own module.

tags.name: AudioRoutingConfigurations
tags.description:
The AudioRoutingConfigurations module is resposible for creating, editing and storing audio routing configurations. You can also use this module to set the active audio routing configuration. Audio configurations have the following parameters:
* **Name**: the name of the configuration
* **Description**: a short description of the configuration
* **Input groups**: a collection of different audio inputs. There are different types of input groups

 * *Floor*: audio from all the active microphones in th room

 * *Ambiance*: enabled Dante audio input when no microphone is active

 * *Language*: the audio coming from the interpreter booths

 * *User*: audio originating from seats defined by the API user

* **Channels**: the routing of the audio (links the input groups to an output group)
* **Output groups**: a collection of audio outputs where you want to route the audio input to. There are different types of output groups available:

 * *Floor*: route audio to speakers of all units present in the room

 * *Language*: route audio to the interpreter booths

 * *User*: route audio to specific seats defined by the API

* **Locked**: protect configuration by locking it with a password
* **Multiple floor**: enable multiple floors to split the Floor out up into two seperate mixes:

 *  a mix for the loudspeakers

 *  a mix for the channel selectors and relays

tags.name: Video
tags.description:
Use the Video module to route the video inputs and outputs to one of the 6 available **video streams**.  To route a video stream you need to set the video input onto one of the video stream and the link a video output group to the same video stream.

With this module you can also make video streams (un)available for delegates. Delegates can only select the streams that are made availalable for delegates on their multimedia unit.

tags.name: VideoConfigurations
tags.description:
The VideoConfigurations module is resposible for creating, editing and storing video routing configurations. You can create new configurations providing the input groups, video streams and output groups. Video configurations have the following parameters:
* **Name**: the name of the video configuration
* **Description**: a short description of the configuration
* **Locked**: protect configuration by locking it. You cannot edit locked configurations. 
* **Input groups**: a group of video input that is available in your Plixus system. There are three types of video input:
 * *Normal* : assign a Video-IN box to one of the available video streams. The content is then always available on the multimedia units.
 
 * *Request* : this group contains the video input from Video-IN boxes combined with a Video-REQUEST panel. The video of the person who presses the request button on their Video-REQUEST (V-REQ)panel is then routed to the video stream. When no one presses the V-REQ, the backup video source is shown. You can only have **one Request group**
 
 * *Talking heads* : contains the video input from units with a webcam. The webcam of the unit becomes active when the delegate activates the microphone. The assigned video stream then displays the video content of the webcam. When no microphone is active you can set a backup video source.
 
* **Video streams**: the 6 available video streams with its routed input and output groups and whether it is enabled or not.  
* **Output groups** (selectorGroups): displays the video source from the routed video input group.

tags.name: Interpretation
tags.description: Use the Interpretation module to retrieve settings from the active configuration, such as the list of listereners per language channel or the current state of all desks. There is also an option to change some settings such as the name of the floor channel or the language list of the room.

tags.name: InterpretationConfigurations
tags.description:
The InterpretationConfigurations module manages the interpretation configurations. With this module you can create new configurations, update exisitng configurations or delete configurations. An interpretation configuration contains the following parameters:
* **Name**: name of the configuration 

* **Description**: a short description of the configuration
* **Locked**: lock a confguration. You cannot modify channels, properties and desk configurations of the locked configuration
* **Enable Audience Indication**: show the amount of units listening to the interpretation 
* **Audience Indication Update Interval**: time interval to update the audience indication 
* **IntraBoothConfiguration**: the desk configuration with the microphoen mode between the desks 
* **interBoothInterpretationMode**: the microphone mode between booths 
* **Enable Slow down**: activate the *Slow down* function  
* **Channels**: the languages contained in this configuration with the routing and the booths 
* **deskConfigurations**: configuration of each desk inside the booth, states the relays and the B and C channel of that desk

tags.name: Discussion
tags.description:
The Discussion module contains the operator functionality of the API. You can:
* Retrieve the **microphone state** of every microphone

* Manage the **default conference settings** of the room such as the microphone mode, microphone activation type and the color of the microphone LED for different microphone states

* View and manage **speaker and request lists**

tags.name: Intercom
tags.description:
With the Intercom module you can use the Intercom functionality of your conference system. In this module you can find calls to: 
* See which seats and booth have intercom enabled
* Enable and disable intertcom
* Request, accept, start and end the intercom conversation using the seat id

tags.name: Recording
tags.description:
Use the Recording module to manage the recording on your central unit. This module contains calls to:
* **Start**, **pause**, **resume** and **stop** the recording

* View and change the **recording settings**
 * Where to store the recording
 
 * Automatically **split** the recording in seperate files after a defined amount of time
 
 * **Prefix** and **suffix** for the file name
 
 * A list of the **recorded channels**

tags.name: Messaging
tags.description:
With the Message module you can **send messages** to seats and booths. For each message you need to define:
* The message itself

* If you want to play a sound for new messages

* Which seats and booths to send the messages to

tags.name: Meeting
tags.description:
With the Meeting module you can manage some basic meetings functions of your conference system. For the actual creation and configuration of your meeting such as the agenda items, you need an external device. The Meeting module contains calls to: 
* Change **meeting states** (Schedule, Prepare, Start, Pause, Resule and End)
* Add and remove **delegates** from the meeting



![alt text](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/televic-conference/plixus-api-docs/master/img/MeetingStates.jpg "Meeting States")

tags.name: Voting
tags.description:
With the Voting module you can do some basic management of voting session. A voting session has the following parameters:

* **Id**: unique identifier

* **State**: state of the voting session, this can be **scheduled**, **running**, **paused** or **ended**
* **Start time**: the start date and time of the session
* **End time**: the end date and time of the session
* **Votes**: the voting results for each seat
* **Voting options**: the different options the meeting participants can choose from. For each voting option you can define the number (defines where the option is shown on the unit), give a description, define a color and select wheter it is possible to abstain
* **Title**: the title of the voting session

tags.name: Buttons
tags.description:
You can use the Buttons module to manage all the buttons inside your room.

> **Warning: changing buttons using the API happens independent of the system logic, therefore API calls may not always be executed.** This is because CoCon controls certain buttons during specific operations such as voting sessions. When the session is finished the button becomes available.

tags.name: Leds
tags.description:
You can use the Buttons module to manage all the buttons inside your room.

> **Warning: changing buttons using the API happens independent of the system logic, therefore API calls may not always be executed.** This is because CoCon controls certain LEDs during specific operations such as voting sessions. When the session is finished the LEDs become available.

tags.name: WirelessAccessPoints
tags.description: This module can be used to retrieve information from and control the behavior of the Wireless Access Points that are connected to the system.

tags.name: WirelessChannels
tags.description: This module can be used to retrieve information about the available wireless channels, as well as to enable and disable these channels

tags.name: WirelessAuthentication
tags.description: The WirelessAuthentication module allows to configure the authentication method used by the wireless access point
